quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: The number one thing is context, no control. That's the reason why we're always encouraging people to see themselves as a business owner.
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: A clear operating principle for empowering teams: provide context instead of directives to drive ownership and better decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: How do you actually solve the puzzle by connecting all the dots together?
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: A mental model for problem-solving that emphasizes systems thinking and integrating disparate information into a coherent whole.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We always have this mentality we are a startup, we're a young company, we're always hungry for growth.
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: A cultural posture that can be applied to maintain speed and ambition even as an organization scales.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: And a very wacky way is like, "How can I run my second half of my marathon faster than the first half?"
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: A counterintuitive metaphor for sustaining (or increasing) pace over time rather than slowing down as complexity grows.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Two, TikTok is quickly becoming one of the biggest advertising platforms alongside Meta and Google, and generated nearly $10 billion in advertising revenue just a couple of years ago.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete data point underscoring TikTok’s scale and why its monetization and operating practices are worth studying.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If you're building a SaaS app, at some point your customers will start asking for enterprise features like SAML authentication and SCIM provisioning.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (WorkOS)
quotes.context: A practical heads-up on the predictable inflection point where SaaS products need enterprise-ready identity features.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Their APIs are easy to understand, so that you can ship quickly and get back to building other features.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (WorkOS)
quotes.context: Emphasizes a prioritization heuristic: reduce integration complexity to preserve product development focus and velocity.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Experimentation is increasingly essential for driving growth and for understanding the performance of new features.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Eppo)
quotes.context: A clear operating principle for modern product teams: use experiments as a core mechanism for growth and feature evaluation.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo helps you increase experimentation velocity while unlocking rigorous deep analysis in a way that no other commercial tool does.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Eppo)
quotes.context: Highlights a dual mandate for experimentation platforms—speed plus rigor—rather than trading one off against the other.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo also makes it easy for you to share experiment insights with your team, sparking new ideas for the A/B testing flywheel.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Eppo)
quotes.context: Introduces a reusable mental model (“A/B testing flywheel”) where sharing insights compounds learning and idea generation.

quotes.topic_title: Google vs TikTok: innovation and global mindset
quotes.text: Number one is really how these two company thinking about innovation. So, I think Google has a very strong philosophy of we're engineering lab and that there's a lot of technology-driven, and a lot of pieces. They are not necessarily always trying to, I would say, cope with the market even, right?
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: Contrasts a tech-led innovation model with a market-led one, useful for diagnosing why products succeed or stall in different org cultures.

quotes.topic_title: Google vs TikTok: innovation and global mindset
quotes.text: However, I think at the TikTok, I think besides the technology part, we do have a very keen, I would say, appetite to really understand what the markets really want and also how can we really service our clients in a better way and the clients here is not necessarily only for advertisers including our user and also creator altogether.
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: Defines a broader, multi-sided “customer” (users, creators, advertisers) as the core unit of product focus—actionable for prioritization and discovery.

quotes.topic_title: Google vs TikTok: innovation and global mindset
quotes.text: And the second one is really thinking about how we take approach on product development. So a lot of times that we take a very rigid approach in terms of product development and oftentimes you see us that experimenting a lot of different things all the same time.
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: Highlights a methodology of running many experiments in parallel, implying a system optimized for fast learning rather than linear roadmaps.

quotes.topic_title: Google vs TikTok: innovation and global mindset
quotes.text: A lot of times that you see a US-born company go global and oftentimes still they are really rooted with the US market and there's nothing wrong with it to be honest, because this is the biggest market for them as I would say for East-born company.
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: Challenges the default assumption that “global” still means “US-first,” framing how company origin shapes global product instincts.

quotes.topic_title: Google vs TikTok: innovation and global mindset
quotes.text: we launched a lot of product not necessarily first in North America. We launched it in South Asia for example, for our shopping, really very big initiative internally for shopping and we launched our really creator fund here in North America. We launched our gaming approach, really serviced our EUI gaming advertisers.
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: Gives concrete examples of market-specific launch sequencing—actionable for teams designing global go-to-market and rollout strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Going global: algorithm plus local market learning
quotes.text: The difference is actually how much you are willing to take the heavy lifting over there in the market. By that I mean really sending your troops into the market, hiring your local talent, understanding the culture and really understanding the behavior from those users.
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: A practical globalization playbook: algorithmic advantage isn’t enough without real local presence and cultural/user-behavior learning.

quotes.topic_title: Going global: algorithm plus local market learning
quotes.text: I understand the machine can do things, but also at the same time that we need to actually get local talent to fine tune the machine.
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: Highlights an actionable operating model: pair ML with local experts to adapt ranking/recommendation systems to each market.

quotes.topic_title: Going global: algorithm plus local market learning
quotes.text: So if we do have a ambition to go global, you have to do one more thing is actually take your step into global. Rather than having the machine do the heavy lifting, you have to really understand in local culture.
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: A counterweight to “the algorithm will figure it out”: global success requires deliberate cultural immersion and on-the-ground learning.

quotes.topic_title: Going global: algorithm plus local market learning
quotes.text: They literally told me at that time is I don't care. I don't care if your ink cartridges or your printer is at the premium quality, maybe the printer I can use, but I can use compatible ink cartridges or toner for that because my consumer won't care about your printing quality or the majority of my consumer won't care.
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: Concrete market-research example showing how local consumer priorities can invalidate “premium quality” positioning assumptions.

quotes.topic_title: Going global: algorithm plus local market learning
quotes.text: If you don't understand the culture, you won't be able to understand the behavior over there.
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: A memorable mental model linking culture → behavior, reinforcing why localization is foundational to product-market fit abroad.

quotes.topic_title: Localizing content and creative recommendations
quotes.text: So these are the things I think different market definitely deserves and demand different kind of treatment and if you are able to do this a lot, you're able to find success over there.
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: Emphasizes a localization-first product mindset: markets require distinct approaches rather than one-size-fits-all algorithms.

quotes.topic_title: Localizing content and creative recommendations
quotes.text: It is actually more food on the TikTok side, like how do you actually introducing new food restaurant or new recipes and also sometimes that you're introducing a new technology. I would say 3C like consumer electronics product over there.
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: Gives a concrete, counterintuitive example of Japan content trends that can guide localization and seeding strategies.

quotes.topic_title: Localizing content and creative recommendations
quotes.text: That's really interesting because you could think it's just this algorithm that figures everything out for you, but I think what you're pointing out is you have to seed it with the right sorts of use cases that that culture is most excited about.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Captures the mental model that algorithms need intentional cultural “seeding,” not just passive learning.

quotes.topic_title: Localizing content and creative recommendations
quotes.text: So a lot of things really depends on how do you actually interpreting the numbers and interpreting the data points but also at the same time your business acumen is going to be very important here to make a judgmental call for some of the situation like that.
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: Highlights the practitioner takeaway that data interpretation must be paired with business judgment, especially in creative decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Localizing content and creative recommendations
quotes.text: I think we're still rely a lot on both machine and also our own experts to analyzing those trends and give it the recommendations.
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: Summarizes the human+machine operating model for creative recommendations: ML for analysis, experts for guidance and decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Culture principle: context, no control
quotes.text: The number one thing resonating really, really well with me is context, no control.
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: Defines TikTok’s core cultural operating principle as a simple, repeatable management framework.

quotes.topic_title: Culture principle: context, no control
quotes.text: A lot of times that these human-made silos is actually slowing things down because humans are not, or our talent, they're not supposed to be categorized into different basket.
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: Challenges role-based siloing as an organizational anti-pattern that reduces speed and impact.

quotes.topic_title: Culture principle: context, no control
quotes.text: That's really why we're always encouraging people to think out of the box and think more and think themselves as a business owner rather than a piece of machine that keep the machine running.
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: Actionable mindset shift: push individuals to operate with ownership rather than narrow task execution.

quotes.topic_title: Culture principle: context, no control
quotes.text: Yeah, I think it's context, no control plus proactive thinking and reactive doing so you have to do more proactive thinking with these contexts.
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: Adds an execution model (“proactive thinking and reactive doing”) that teams can adopt alongside autonomy.

quotes.topic_title: Culture principle: context, no control
quotes.text: But just like how I see some of my friends, their kids playing Legos, if you don't really see the full picture, you won't be able to make the Lego as a one thing at the end of the day. You have to see the other pieces.
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: Memorable metaphor for why broad context enables cross-team collaboration and coherent outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring for autonomy: curiosity, discipline, prioritization
quotes.text: The key there is to hire very high quality people and very high caliber people because if not, then things won't work out too great.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights the core tradeoff of high-autonomy cultures: freedom only works with consistently strong talent.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring for autonomy: curiosity, discipline, prioritization
quotes.text: Curiosity is a very important quality when I'm actually talking to my interviewers because I want to see that they are naturally curious to new things.
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: Gives a concrete hiring signal for autonomy-heavy environments: screen explicitly for intrinsic curiosity.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring for autonomy: curiosity, discipline, prioritization
quotes.text: And the other thing is the discipline because like I said, it is actually a double-edged sword in this case.
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: Frames autonomy as risky without discipline, offering a memorable mental model for why “freedom” can create chaos.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring for autonomy: curiosity, discipline, prioritization
quotes.text: One of the good example that is the ability to prioritize because I don't believe one thing is everybody can do everything. You have to prioritize properly so that you're able to push the right agenda.
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: Connects autonomy to prioritization as a required skill: choosing what not to do is essential when opportunities are abundant.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring for autonomy: curiosity, discipline, prioritization
quotes.text: it is hard, don't get me wrong. It is really hard to say that we can find everyone like that, but we would love to believe that we can train our employees like that so that they're able to even do better in their longer-term career.
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: Adds a practical hiring-and-development approach: you won’t find perfect candidates, so invest in training these autonomy traits.

quotes.topic_title: Always day one and tight cross-functional closeness
quotes.text: Yeah, another internal thing that we always say is always day one, we want to make sure that we always have this mentality we are a startup. We are a young company. We're always hungry for growth.
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: A repeatable cultural mantra (“always day one”) that teams can use to preserve urgency and growth mindset even at scale.

quotes.topic_title: Always day one and tight cross-functional closeness
quotes.text: I see there is I can talk to anyone at any time via our internal communication system. I can ping Shuo right now. I can ping the co-founder if I want to tomorrow.
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: A concrete example of low-friction access across levels that enables fast feedback loops and reduces organizational drag.

quotes.topic_title: Always day one and tight cross-functional closeness
quotes.text: Is that creating some of the, I would say chaotic situation? It might be, but I do think that this keeps the company very energetic. People are willing to share, people are willing to engage. That's very important.
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: A counterintuitive tradeoff: allowing some chaos can increase energy, engagement, and information flow.

quotes.topic_title: Always day one and tight cross-functional closeness
quotes.text: I have never seen a company, the engineering team and the product team and the sales team are so close.
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: Highlights unusually tight cross-functional proximity as a differentiator practitioners can intentionally design for.

quotes.topic_title: Always day one and tight cross-functional closeness
quotes.text: if your engineer does not really know what the market wants and if your PM doesn't really know what is actually the client's feedback, they won't be able to get a right product in the market. They just won't be.
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: Actionable warning that product-market fit depends on engineers and PMs directly understanding market needs and customer feedback.

quotes.topic_title: Mechanisms: big doc-read meetings and client immersion
quotes.text: But one thing we keep really well is actually we are using a reading format of meeting. So it's a doc reading. We just read in comments and understanding the context again. It is the doc, bring everybody together, and then we discuss the things that we want to make a decision with or the things that we feel is a blocker or things that we need to celebrate.
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: A concrete meeting mechanism (doc-reading format) for aligning a large cross-functional group before decision-making.

quotes.topic_title: Mechanisms: big doc-read meetings and client immersion
quotes.text: That meeting is 180 people-ish. It's crazy to have a meeting at that size, especially that there are different kind of functionality there.
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: A specific, counterintuitive example that very large meetings can work when structured correctly.

quotes.topic_title: Mechanisms: big doc-read meetings and client immersion
quotes.text: So that meeting structure keep everybody together and consensus, again, not necessarily only for the top leaders.
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: Highlights an alignment model that intentionally extends beyond leadership to build shared context and buy-in.

quotes.topic_title: Mechanisms: big doc-read meetings and client immersion
quotes.text: We invited them together to these immersion trips recorded to really get face time with our clients, to really feel the heat.
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: An actionable practice for feeding first-hand customer pain directly to PMs and engineers via client immersion.

quotes.topic_title: Mechanisms: big doc-read meetings and client immersion
quotes.text: I think oftentimes it is a battle. It is not necessarily the general, you have to stay in the back, you sometimes have to go to the front, but we just make sure that the general go to the front quite often in our company to do that.
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: A memorable leadership mental model: leaders and senior ICs should regularly engage directly with customers rather than staying removed.

quotes.topic_title: Moving fast: global org design and frequent team iteration
quotes.text: I think the value, if I put it in a very reactive way is, "How can I run my second half of my marathon faster than the first half?"
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for sustaining speed as a company scales—optimizing for acceleration over time, not just early momentum.

quotes.topic_title: Moving fast: global org design and frequent team iteration
quotes.text: So we set up teams really across the board in the global locations to really acquire global talent who knows the market and who knows the competition, too.
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: Actionable org-design advice: place teams in key markets to gain local market and competitive intelligence as a built-in advantage.

quotes.topic_title: Moving fast: global org design and frequent team iteration
quotes.text: So for example, we have the majority of the engineer and also PMs currently located in the west coast of North America, so Los Angeles and also San Jose.
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: A concrete example of how they cluster product/engineering in specific hubs to move fast while operating globally.

quotes.topic_title: Moving fast: global org design and frequent team iteration
quotes.text: The stability is important, don't get me wrong, but I do think that as a faster growing company, we need to consistently to reiterate not only the product but also our teams.
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: A counterweight to conventional org thinking: frequent team iteration is positioned as necessary for high-growth environments.

quotes.topic_title: Moving fast: global org design and frequent team iteration
quotes.text: Not necessarily we're bonding to one team structure. We're actually bonding to the market need and we're bounding to the growth we're looking for.
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: A clear principle for org agility: optimize around market demand and growth goals rather than preserving static team structures.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Customers always seem to want to give you their data in the messiest possible CSV file.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical reality teams should plan for: real-world customer data is often messy by default.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And building a spreadsheet importer becomes a never-ending sink for your engineering and support resources.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Warns that DIY CSV/spreadsheet import can turn into ongoing operational drag, not a one-time build.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Six months later you're fixing yet another date conversion edge case bug.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides a concrete example of the long tail of edge cases that makes data import deceptively costly.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Customers get frustrated by useless messages like, "Error on line 53," and never end up getting started with your product.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Connects poor import UX directly to activation failure, emphasizing onboarding as a product growth lever.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: OneSchema intelligently corrects messy data so that your customers don't have to spend hours in Excel just to get started with your product.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Frames an actionable approach: reduce customer effort at the data-import step to accelerate time-to-value.

quotes.topic_title: Early go-to-market mistakes: hiring and control mindset
quotes.text: The first mistake I made was... By the way, the goal is to hiring 100 people in a six month to support the go-to-market. That is the speed we're into. So that is early 2020 to middle of 2020. So within six months I need to hire, I would say, 100 people to supporting the global go-to-market structure and build everything. Then the first mistake I made just at the right point because we're trying to grow too fast and sometimes as a hiring manager I have to compromise the standard we're trying to hire. So that's the mistakes I think I made first and I think nobody should repeat that mistake is you need to always run for the quality rather than the quantity.
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: A concrete scaling example (100 hires in 6 months) paired with the actionable hiring principle to prioritize quality over speed.

quotes.topic_title: Early go-to-market mistakes: hiring and control mindset
quotes.text: But I would say, believe me when I say this, this is a pain, right, when you have the wrong people on the team, it's not necessarily going to make you move faster, it's going to actually slow you down.
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: Counterintuitive reminder that headcount growth can reduce velocity if hiring standards slip.

quotes.topic_title: Early go-to-market mistakes: hiring and control mindset
quotes.text: But literally what you don't know is your goal is not to deliver the go-to-market strategy. Your goal is to land your go-to-market strategy with sales together.
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: A memorable reframing of success from producing strategy to ensuring adoption and execution with sales.

quotes.topic_title: Early go-to-market mistakes: hiring and control mindset
quotes.text: So it's very important that the leader at any level needs to be situational. You cannot always down to the wheat and you cannot really distance yourself from the reality. So you need to find the balance to really get engaged and also see yourself out there to getting, I would say, getting deeper into the problems, to identify the problems, and then you're able to perform even better.
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: Actionable leadership guidance to balance delegation with staying close enough to market reality to spot and solve real problems.

quotes.topic_title: Who struggles at TikTok: lifestyle fit and intensity
quotes.text: join a start-up and join a rocket ship is a lifestyle. It is not necessarily a job you are working on from 9 to 5. So it is a different lifestyle and it is not built for everyone.
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: Reframes attrition as a lifestyle/pace mismatch rather than a competence failure—useful for hiring, onboarding, and self-selection.

quotes.topic_title: Who struggles at TikTok: lifestyle fit and intensity
quotes.text: I can see a lot of people that they left and become very successful, too. So it is not necessarily that, "Oh, we think you're not good and then you're going to be not good for every single other company." That's not the case.
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: Counters the common narrative that leaving/being let go implies low ability; emphasizes context-dependent success.

quotes.topic_title: Who struggles at TikTok: lifestyle fit and intensity
quotes.text: oftentimes my last question during my interview is, "What is actually your goal in the next three to five years?"
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: A concrete interview tactic to assess fit and align role expectations with a candidate’s medium-term career direction.

quotes.topic_title: Who struggles at TikTok: lifestyle fit and intensity
quotes.text: "Hey, I don't think this is the job for you forever. Nobody going to work in this forever. If you can, great. But what is really your North Star?"
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: A retention-and-development mental model: treat roles as chapters and explicitly co-plan around an employee’s “North Star.”

quotes.topic_title: Who struggles at TikTok: lifestyle fit and intensity
quotes.text: I think at the end of the day it's a personal choice. It's very much like a personal choice.
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: Positions intensity and hours as an individual decision shaped by motivation and life stage, not just company pressure.

quotes.topic_title: OKRs and planning: alignment with iteration
quotes.text: It is definitely a company alignment that we are using OKR as our basically the system to make sure that everybody is working towards the same goal.
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: Frames OKRs primarily as an alignment mechanism (a system), not just a goal-setting ritual.

quotes.topic_title: OKRs and planning: alignment with iteration
quotes.text: Again, it's very important to align on the OKRs because I can see a lot of times the OKRs are putting in, but they are very siloed and that is not really necessarily helpful for the company want achieving really high growth.
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: Highlights a common OKR failure mode—siloed OKRs—and ties it directly to limiting growth.

quotes.topic_title: OKRs and planning: alignment with iteration
quotes.text: The structure is, basically the guidance is, using the key result to evaluating and then you put the steps in between.
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: A practical methodology: define measurable KRs first, then backfill the plan/steps.

quotes.topic_title: OKRs and planning: alignment with iteration
quotes.text: And also oftentimes your output is other people's input.
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for cross-functional dependencies when defining OKRs and execution plans.

quotes.topic_title: OKRs and planning: alignment with iteration
quotes.text: Yeah, we do have annual planning cycle, but I have to say that our annual planning cycle is the baseline. We often do a lot of iterations in the middle of the year and also on a quarterly basis that we're able to pivoting really nimbly to really catering to the things that we see in the market.
quotes.speaker: Ray Cao
quotes.context: Describes a planning approach that treats annual plans as a starting point, with frequent quarterly pivots driven by market signals.
